questiontext.text:
We have seen how to find the partial fractions decomposition for rational functions where the denominator is made up of distinct linear factors, or a single repeated linear factor. Clearly, these are not all of the possibilities?

In fact, there are some other cases to consider. If we fully factorise the denominator, there are four possible kinds of term which can arise:

  • Distinct linear factor, e.g. \((x+1)\)

  • Repeated linear factor, e.g. \((x+1)^3\)

  • Distinct quadratic factor, e.g. \((x^2+1)\)

  • Repeated quadratic factor, e.g. \((x^2+1)^2\)

Note that the quadratic factors will only remain if their discriminant is negative, otherwise we could have factorised them into linear factors.


Partial Fraction Decomposition

To construct the partial fraction decomposition for a rational function, fully factorise the denominator then for each factor, add terms as follows:

Type of factor   Form of factor     Partial fractions to add  
Distinct linear factor \((x-a)\) \(\dfrac{A}{x-a}\)
Repeated linear factor \((x-a)^n\) \(\dfrac{A_1}{(x-a)}+\dfrac{A_2}{(x-a)^2}+\cdots+\dfrac{A_n}{(x-a)^n}\)
Distinct quadratic factor \((ax^2+bx+c)\) \(\dfrac{Ax+B}{(ax^2+bx+c)}\)
Repeated quadratic factor \((ax^2+bx+c)^n\) \(\dfrac{A_1x+B_1}{(ax^2+bx+c)}+\cdots+\dfrac{A_nx+B_n}{(ax^2+bx+c)^n}\)

Examples

  • \(\dfrac{x^2-x+2}{x(x-1)^2}\) will have partial fractions in the form \(\dfrac{A}{x} + \dfrac{B}{x-1}+ \dfrac{C}{(x-1)^2}\).

  • \(\dfrac{4x-1}{(x+1)^2(x^2+3)}\) will have partial fractions in the form \(\dfrac{A}{x+1}+\dfrac{B}{(x+1)^2}+\dfrac{Cx+D}{x^2+3}\).
